subject: Re: [junit] Article That Should Help Testing: "Five Habits of Highly Profitable Software Dev
msgSnippet: ... Ok, in all seriousness this time. :-) I disagree with your first point. First, the naming convention tells you that a method is a constructor.

On 8/24/06, robertjmiller_jgs <robertjmiller_jgs@...> wrote:
> Hello,
>
> Today, I have a test related article being published on java.net:
> "Five Habits of Highly Profitable Software Developers"
> http://today.java.net/pub/a/today/2006/08/24/five-habits-of-highly-profitable-developers.html

Ok, in all seriousness this time. :-)

I disagree with your first point. First, the naming convention tells
you that a method is a constructor. Understanding Java should tell you
everything you need to know about why that method is there. A
constructor's job is to ensure that an object is usable and "ready to
rock" when it's handed off. Part of an object being "ready to rock",
is that it should be fully loaded and in a guaranteed valid state.
Telling people to do the least amount possible in a constructor is
encouraging them to hand out objects that are (potentially) in an
invalid internal state. That will get you a "reading of the riot act"
on any project that I'm leading. An object must _always_ have a valid
internal state. As programs run in more and more multithreaded
environments these days, this rule becomes even more important. You
_never_ know when your object might be accessed, therefore it should
_always_ be ready for access.

I agree with point two, but sometimes naming conventions carry as much
meaning as a long method name. For example, a Struts Action object has
an "execute" method; that's a short name and while it may seem that it
could benefit from expansion, in the context of a Struts application,
it has a very well defined and understood meaning. (Kind of like
constructors. :-)

Point five. I agree up to a point. There will always be some things
that need to be done in specific sequences. Opening and closing files
leaps to mind at this point.

Simon
